`` As it has grown into the dominant company in Silicon Valley, Google has lost some of its entrepreneurial culture and become a slower-moving bureaucracy, analysts and insiders say,'' Miller and Helft report. To counter this, the company announced that Larry Page, its 38-year-old co-founder, would take over as chief executive from Eric Schmidt , a technology industry veteran who was brought in a decade ago to provide adult supervision, as Silicon Valley calls it. shakeup of its top management, announcing that co-founder Larry Page will replace Eric Schmidt as chief executive of the internet giant in April. Google said Eric Schmidt would remain with the company as executive chairman, focusing on deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships. He would act as an adviser to Page and Google's other co-founder, Sergey Brin , who would work on strategic projects and new products. The management changes were due to take effect on April

BGC Partners analyst Colin Gillis said that Google experienced tremendous growth under Eric Schmidt , becoming a search and advertising powerhouse, although the company also arguably experienced a number of missteps and missed opportunities. A case can also be made that the company has not built any new material revenue streams, was late to building for the mobile market, has no effective social solutions, overbuilt its headcount and placed itself in the crosshairs of government regulators, Gillis said. Editor-in-chief of technology blog SearchEngineLand.com Danny Sullivan said Google's biggest challenges now are to`` prove that they've got their Mojo back and that nobody needs to fear them.''
